direction.raw_text: We're at the funeral of Dorothy Kowalski. In attendance are mostly old folks, their offspring and several bored teenagers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands towards the front of the church. He speaks to an older MAN in a bulky, out-of-date suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm real sorry about Dorothy, Walt. She was a real peach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for coming, Al. Walt Kowalski looks young for his age. He has slate blue eyes, physically fit and has had the same buzz cut hairstyle since getting out of the military in 1953. Walt is also a perfectionist. Nothing escapes his hawklike eyes, eyes that pierce and judge. Walt looks around at how the young people have dressed at his wife's funeral. His eyes narrow at his GRANDDAUGHTER's belly button ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ. Walt's two sons, MITCH and STEVE, watch their father from across the pews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at the Old Man glaring at Ashley. He can't even tone it down at Mom's funeral?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you expect? Dad's still living in the 50s. He expects his granddaughter to dress a little more modestly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well your kid's wearing a Timberwolves jersey. I'm sure Dad appreciates that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My point is that there's nothing anyone can do that won't disappoint the Old Man. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's inevitable. That's why we stopped doing Thanksgivings; the deal with the boat motor, the broken bird bath, it's always something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we going to do with him? Don't you think he'll get in trouble by himself over in the old neighborhood?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you have him move in with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ha ha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The choir sings the Beatitudes. Walt looks around disgustedly at the people gathered as one woman looks through her day planner, an old guy dozes and his Granddaughter Ashley applies nail polish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the very young parish priest, steps up to the altar and delivers the eulogy for Walt's wife. Walt sits ramrod straight and listens to the thin, weak, unconvincing words of Father Janovich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Death... is often a bittersweet occasion to us Catholics. Bitter in the pain it causes the deceased ... and their families. Sweet to those who know the salvation that awaits them. And some may ask, what is death. Is it the end? Or is it the beginning? And what is life? What is this thing we call life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus. Walt coughs. He takes a handkerchief and wipes his lips. He looks down and notices a speck of BLOOD on the white cloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The house is crammed with people following the service. Walt doesn't know what to do with himself. He has to keep busy. Steve steps over to his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lot of people showed up after the service.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, I s'pose they knew there'd be plenty of ham. I think I'll go downstairs and get some more chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do it, Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw, we need them now, not next week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandsons JOSH, DANIEL and DAVID look through boxes in the cellar. A box of old Korea War photos are pawed through. Josh holds up a black-and-white PHOTO -- a young WALT looks utterly exhausted, behind him six bodies are sprawled dead on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that Dad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's Grandpa Walt. Josh turns the photo over and reads it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Third Platoon, E company, March second, 1952, Korea.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Korea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell if I know? David holds up a MEDAL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cool, I found a medal. They hear someone coming downstairs. By the time Walt descends the staircase, the boys sit on the couch, pretending to be doing nothing. Walt gives them a hard look as he grabs some chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People eat and chat. Ashley marches over to her parents,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and Mitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long do we have to stay, this ghetto is a dead zone for my cell and I'm bored. Walt stands behind them with an armful of folding chairs, he overheard his Granddaughter. Mitch and Karen are embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ashley, honey. Why don't you help Grandpa Walt with the chairs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa Walt, can I help you with the chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take care of it, you just painted your nails. Walt opens the folding chairs and looks out the window. It's snowing. Walt puts on his coat, he almost looks relieved to get out of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd better salt the sidewalk before someone falls and breaks a hip. Walt taps the floor with his boot and DAISY, his very, very, very old DOG follows him outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WALT'S HOUSE - EVENING 6 6 Walt carefully shovels his sidewalk. He deliberately stops at the boundary of his property. The reason for this is that Walt's neighbors are now mostly Asians who moved into the house that once belonged to Polish families. Next door to Walt's house some sort of party is going on. Walt can see through the window that the living room is jammed with at least forty people, all Asians, all Hmong. And this is a problem for Walt, because Walt is a full- blown, unrepentant racist. Walt lights a cigarette and speaks to his dog, Daisy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, how many swamp rats can they cram into a living room? Walt spits in the snow and walks back to the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt steps inside and catches Ashley sneaking a cigarette. She has pulled back the canvas tarp that covers his pride and joy, his beloved 1972 GRAN TORINO. The Gran Torino is in mint condition. It has been babied since the day it rolled off the line. Ashley tosses her cigarette when she sees Grandpa Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow, Grandpa, when'd you get the vintage car? Walt looks at her for a second, then steps on her still burning cigarette before answering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never knew you had a cool old car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's only been in here since before you were born.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, what are you like going to do with it like, when... you die? Walt lights up a smoke -- WALT Jesus, Joseph and Mary. Walt pulls the cover back over the Gran Torino.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what about that super cool retro couch in the den, I'm going to State next year and I don't have, like, any furniture? Walt walks out without commenting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doorbell rings and Walt opens the door. Standing there is TAO, a sixteen-year-old HMONG boy. Walt scowls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is slight, he has long hair, long lashes, but is very good-looking -- like an Asian Johnny Depp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the hell are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (very quietly) I'm Tao, I live next door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?! Speak up, boy, get the shit out of your mouth. What do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have jumper cables? My uncle's car is old and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. And have some goddamned respect, zipper head, we're mourning over here. Walt slams the door in Tao's face. Walt turns and is suddenly cornered by Father Janovich. Walt hates situations like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 8 FATHER JANOVICH How you holding up, Walt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Kowalski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Mr. Kowalski, not Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, Mr. Kowalski. Your wife and I became quite close these last few months. She asked that I watch over you when she passed on. I told her I watch out for my entire flock, but she made me promise I'd keep an extra sharp eye on you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I appreciate your kindness to my wife and now that you've spoken your piece, why don't you move on to the next sheep? Walt starts to step away, but Father Janovich blocks him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorothy mentioned specifically that it was her wish for you to go to confession. She said she couldn't remember the last time you went.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is. Walt drains his lowball glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I confess I never much liked church and only went because of the wife. And I confess I have no desire to confess to a boy who is fresh out of the seminary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WALT'S HOUSE - LATER 9 9 People are leaving Walt's house. A mass of shuffling, stiff-jointed old Pollacks. Right next door -- walking the opposite direction are more Hmong going up the sidewalk. They laugh and chatter and carry big dishes of food and fruit. They are a happy bunch compared to the dour crowd exiting Walt's home. The Hmong are going to a birth ceremony. A three-day-old baby is named and three souls are located for the newborn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt leans over a car that contains two shivering old ladies from the funeral. He hooks up the jumper cables to their dead battery. Mitch, Karen, Ashley and Josh pull up next to Walt in a brand new Toyota Land Cruiser. Mitch opens the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd really like to help, Dad, but we have to get the kids home, they're getting restless. Walt just looks at the TOYOTA EMBLEM on the Land Cruiser and then gives Mitch a disgusted glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll call in a few, see how you're doing. Walt nods and lights a cigarette as they drive off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kill you to buy American.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you see him look at the truck? It's always Rice-Burner this or Jap-Buggy that. Even at Mom's funeral, he can't let it go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least he didn't say anything this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He didn't have to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what do you expect? The man worked at a Ford plant for twenty- eight years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I suppose that's my goddamned fault?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt gets his guests' engine running. As they drive off, Walt hears faint SINGING. Walt looks into his neighbor's backyard and can't believe his eyes. The Hmong all sing and chant as three CHICKENS have their heads sliced off, right there in the yard. The chickens are held up and everyone chants louder. It's a sacrifice. Walt spits in the snow and says to Daisy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbarians. Goddamned barbarians.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The house is a buzz of activity. The older Hmong speak their native language, the younger generation speaks both English and Hmong. (NOTE: Hmong is subtitled when necessary.) Tao's Grandmother (PHONG) complains to a MAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no man in this house, that's why my daughter should remarry. Being a second wife is better than having a woman be the head of the household. It's not our way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 11 MAN (SUBTITLED) What about Tao?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the man in the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao's not a man. (GESTURES) Look at him in the kitchen, washing dishes like a woman. Even his sister gives him orders and he obeys. The CAMERA PANS TO the kitchen where TAO washes a pile of dishes. An older relative drops dishes in the sink, without acknowledging Tao's presence. It's clearly an insult. In the LIVING ROOM the Hmong Soul Calling ceremony starts its next phase. An elder, the family SHAMAN, is present and begins the ritual. As the entire Hmong family gathers to watch. Tao slips on his coat and goes out the back door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao wobbles as he pedals his bike through the snow. Tao passes Walt's garage and is startled as Walt appears from a shadow, JUMPER CABLES in his hands. They make eye contact as Tao passes. Walt spits in the snow and looks down at Daisy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought these zips were supposed to be such hard workers. Christ, I had my own car when I was his age.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao exits the store, gets on his bike and rides off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 12 A few blocks away, Tao rides past a snowbank when -- WHAM! A HOCKEY STICK is thrown through the spokes of his front wheel. Tao flies over the handlebars into the snow. A chorus of laughter is heard. Three LATINOS stand around the stunned, prone Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatta you gonna do, gook? You gonna Kung Fu' us? Tao just lies there as Latino #2 picks up his bike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #2 Surprised it ain't a girl's bike. The Latinos laugh. Tao remains on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gonna get up or what? Tao doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell you what, I'll let you take the first swing. You drop me and you can have your bike back. Tao smiles, he can't help it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck you smiling at, gook? Something funny? He grabs Tao by the jacket and pulls him to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better get the fuck outta here, bitch. He pushes Tao backwards. Tao falls back into the snow. This time Tao crab-walks back away from the Latinos. The Latinos stroll away with Tao's bike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : THREE MONTHS LATER Walt is going about the chores of spring cleaning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 13 Walt looks around with disdain at his neighbors' houses. Walt's property is perfectly kept, whereas his neighbors' houses are rundown. Walt's eyes linger on every defect, gutter hangs, ripped screen doors, peeling paint. One neighbor has installed a chicken coop. Walt looks down at Daisy -- WALT Damn chinks let their yards go to hell. Polarski would turn over in his grave if he could see what they did to his lawn. Tao walks past. Walt watches him pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know why these goddamned slopes had to move to my block. This used to be a nice neighborhood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao nods to an older woman rocking in a broken rocking chair. PHONG nods back to Tao, then turns her evil eye back on Walt, whom she's been seething at all morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why doesn't that stupid, hairy white man move? He must be too dumb to realize he's not welcome here. All the Mee-Khah left in the neighborhood should just move away. Look at him strut like a rooster. She sees Walt glance at her and spit. Phong glares back and spits beetle juice, which has turned her teeth black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daisy snoozes next to the front door. The doorbell rings; Daisy doesn't even move. Walt walks to the front door holding a roll of duct tape. The doorbell rings again. Walt looks down at Daisy -- 12.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 14 WALT Jesus Christ, dog, have you gone totally deaf? Walt opens the door. Standing on his front step is Father Janovich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi there, Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, son, you're not my barber, you're not a friend, so why in the hell do you think you can call me Walt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry... Mr. Kowalski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, what are you peddling now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, nothing. Thought I'd drop by and see how you were doing. Haven't seen you in church in awhile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. You've done your good deed, now why don't you run along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd really like to talk, Mr. Kowalski.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so, kid. Sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Do you have a problem with me, Mr. Kowalski?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't want to know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The problem is I think you're an overeducated, 27-year-old virgin who holds the hands of superstitious old women and promises them eternity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 15 Walt shuts the front door in Father Janovich's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao walks down the street, his head in a book. He finally realizes there's a blue Chevy following slowly behind him. The blue Chevy is now parallel with Tao and keeps pace with his step. Tao looks over to the occupants of the Chevy. It's two LATINOS. Tao quickens his pace, but the Chevy easily keeps up with Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is you a boy or a girl, I can't tell?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #2 What you reading, gook, Jackass And The Rice Stalk? Tao laughs, but keeps walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, you keep walking. Fucking slopes everywhere you look, man. Why gooks come up in here and fuck up our neighborhood? Down the street -- is a suped-up HONDA CIVIC with a big
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the back. Inside are five Hmong gangbangers. The Hmong gangbangers notice Tao being followed by the Latinos. SPIDER, the driver, squints and then points at Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dude, that's my little cousin, Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure about that, Spider?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure. Do we do something... or what? Smokie is the gang leader. He looks at Tao for a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your cousin tight with anyone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 16 SPIDER No, he flies solo, Smokie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Let's go help out our little cousin. Smokie nods to Spider, they roar up and stop right across from Tao and the Latinos' car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better not be giving my bro here a hard time or you're gonna wish you never been born.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh goody, more Rice Niggers. The Latino Driver smiles and flashes a PISTOL. A Hmong kid in the back seat opens the door and displays a sub-machine gun. The Latinos are way out-gunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #2 Fucking Viet Cong swamp rats. Go back to your fucking rice paddy. The Latinos screech their tires and are gone. The Hmongs in the car smile and congratulate themselves. Tao simply keeps walking down the street!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the fuck does he think he's going? Turn us around and go after that cousin of yours. They swing a U-turn and pull up to Tao, keeping pace with him as he walks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, cuz, slow down, where you going? You should really think about hanging with us, man. If we all stick together, shit like that won't happen, with those Spicks. Tao nods as he walks, but doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't be such a little girl. You join up with us, we'll keep you out of trouble, cuz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 17 Tao looks at the sub-machine gun cradled by the Hmong gangbanger in the back seat. Smokie takes this all in. He looks down the street and sees that in a half block, Tao will have to pass a group of Latino gangbanger types.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think about it and we'll see you tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao digs in the garden. Tao's younger sister SUE sits and reads JANE magazine on the porch. The tricked-out Honda with Blue Neon lights pulls up. Spider, Smokie and two other Hmong gangbangers get out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, cuz. Hey, Sue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Came to talk to my cousin Tao. Smokie looks over to Sue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spider, who's the other cousin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: laughs at the name Spider. Sue is seventeen, has long straight hair with red highlights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spider'? Is that what he just called you, Fong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my little cousin, Sue. Smokie takes off his sunglasses and smiles at Sue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Sue... how old are you, girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mentally, I'm way too old for you. I'm going inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 18 SPIDER That's right, go inside while the men talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that's exactly what I'm doing, Fong. Sue rolls her eyes and goes inside. Smokie stares at Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think about what we talked about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Smokie watches Tao carefully, offers him a cigarette. Tao shakes his head no and looks at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's exactly the point, Tao. Spider told me how everyone thinks you're a pushover, how everybody walks all over you and shit. I mean, look at you, out here working in the garden like a woman. Tao nods silently, but still looks at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It ain't no big thing. You just need a little guidance. Tao looks up at Smokie. Tao looks a little skeptical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true, man. Shit, I used to be kind of a quiet little punk like you, everybody fucking with me. But finally I said no more.' You, you're lucky, Tao, we got your back. Me? I didn't have nobody. Had to mold my own tribe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smokie's right. We're family, right? You with us or what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swear, brother, we're the best friends you'll ever have. And anyone fucks with you, they're fucked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 19 SPIDER Come on, man. Tao clears his throat and speaks for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I have to do? Smokie points to Walt's open garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spider mentioned that neighbor of yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARAGE ZOOM IN -- There it sits with the tarp rolled back, Walt's gorgeous, shining GRAN TORINO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Now that's a car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Shit ya. 1972 Gran Torino fastback. Cobra jet engine. Mint. Next to the garage, Walt is bent over planting tomatoes. Walt notices the Hmong punks looking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt sits at the bar in the VFW (Veterans of Foreign Wars) drinking with the old buddies and cracking off- color jokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got one. A Mexican, a Jew and a colored guy walk into a bar, the bartender looks up at them and says -- get the fuck out.' The gang laughs, until they see Father Janovich step up to the bar. He smiles as he recognizes several faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, here's where my flock congregates when they're not in church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 20 MEL Hiya, Father J.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Mel. Hey there, Darrel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Walt. Walt says nothing. He just sips his beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What brings you in here, Father? The meat raffle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I came down to talk to Walt, if that's okay. Mel and Darrel look at Walt. It puts him on the spot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to hand it to you, Padre. You are persistent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promised your wife. Walt looks over at Mel and Darrel and then back at Father Janovich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jesus Christ, let's grab a booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waitress comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have a Pabst and a shot. What are you having, Father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have a Diet Coke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit, this is a bar, what do you want to drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 21 FATHER JANOVICH Ummmm... I'll have a gin and tonic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attaboy. The waitress leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, what do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promised your wife I'd get you to go to confession.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, why'd you do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was very insistent. She made me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure are fond of promising people stuff you can't deliver on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's talk about something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Life and death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What would you know about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to think I know a lot. I'm a priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You stand at the altar and preach on and on about life and death without knowing anything other than what you learned in priest school. Everything you say sounds like it's out of the Rookie Preachers Handbook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know about that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 22 Walt waves his hand and cuts him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Death is bittersweet? Bitter in the pain, sweet in the salvation.' That's what you know of life and death? Good God, it's pathetic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you know, Mr. Kowalski?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plenty. I lived with death for three years in Korea. We shot people, we stabbed them with bayonets, we hacked seventeen-year- old kids to death with shovels, for Christ's sake. I did things that won't leave me till the day I die, horrible things, things I have to live with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what about life? Walt has to think for a second. He struggles with his answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... I survived the war... got married... and raised a family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like you know more about death than you do living. Walt downs a shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt hears a sound and wakes up. He's very groggy, he had plenty to drink at the VFW.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daisy? The dog sleeps in her bed in the corner. Walt looks at the clock; it's 3:48 am. Walt looks out his bedroom window. He sees the faint beam of a flashlight in his garage.

direction.raw_text: PAGE 23 WALT Son of a bitch. Walt pulls on his robe, opens the closet and pulls out the big, 30-06 M1 Garand Rifle he took home from Korea. Walt slides a magazine into the top of the M1 and chambers a round with a loud SNAP.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The light flips on and before he can blink, Tao is face to face with the barrel of Walt's M1 RIFLE. Walt is silent, he has one eye closed so he can better aim at Tao's forehead -- which is nine inches away. Tao drops the tool he was holding, it bounces with a loud metallic clang. Tao backs away, his eyes wide with terror. As Tao backs up, Walt advances, step for step. Tao trips over a garden hose, which causes Walt to trip. They both start to fall. The lightbulb is bumped with the rifle barrel and swings back and forth. As Walt hits the garage floor, he accidentally FIRES THE RIFLE. The bullet goes through a big, metal Hamm's Beer sign on the wall. Tao scrambles to his feet and jumps like a deer over Walt. Tao runs out of the garage and into the night. Walt lies on the floor for a second, stunned. Sweat runs down his forehead. He coughs up blood. The lightbulb still swings, casting odd shadows in the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit.

Walt goes in the back door and a moment later the kitchen light comes on. The Gran Torino remains in the driveway. It's a challenge, an invitation. Walt is daring the thief to come back. And Walt's ready this time.

direction.raw_text: I've been thinking about our discussion on life and death. About what you said. About how you carry around the horrible things you were forced to do. Horrible things that won't leave you. It seems that it would do you good to unload some of that burden. Things done during war are terrible, being ordered to kill, killing to save others, killing to save yourself. You're right, those are things I don't know anything about. But I do know about forgiveness. And I've seen a lot of men who have confessed their sins, admitted their guilt and left their burdens behind them. Stronger men than you. Men at war who were ordered to do appalling things and are now at peace. Walt nods. Father Janovich threw a bull's-eye. Almost.

ALL the signatures have been written in a woman's cursive style and with the same pen. Mitch slides a wrapped gift across the table to Walt.

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just open it. Walt opens the package, it's a Gopher Reaching Tool -- the kind that has an alligator clamp so you can pick up objects that have fallen behind the stove, etc. Walt looks at his son and daughter-in-law.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a Gopher. It's so you can reach stuff. You know, it makes things easier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's one from me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slides over a another wrapped gift. Walt opens it. It's a PHONE with really big numbers for old people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 44 KAREN It's a phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Karen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just thought... we thought that it would... make things easier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I see that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing wrong with making things less hard on yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karen's right, Dad. You've worked hard your whole life. Maybe you should think about taking it a little easier? Walt lights up a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's another thing, Dad. You should get rid of the coffin nails. Walt says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the house, now that Mom's gone, it's got to be a lot to maintain, let alone clean... and you're all alone in here. It's worse than Walt thought. He puffs smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's these great places now, these communities where you don't have to worry about mowing the lawn or shoveling snow. People who are like you, alert, active, but are alone and would benefit by being with other folks their own age.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 45 MITCH Dad, take a look. We brought some pamphlets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch and Karen storm out to their Land Cruiser. Mitch carries the Gopher Grabber Tool and Karen has the big numbered phone in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, I told you this was a bad idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, you were right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son of a bitch! He just won't let anyone help him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we tried. Now we can just drop it. No one can say we didn't try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To hell with him, kicking us out on his birthday?! We should've stayed home with Ashley and Josh. They knew better, they wouldn't even come. The goddamned kids are smarter than we are! Mitch screeches the tires as they take off. Walt waits for them to clear out, before coming out on the porch with a can of Pabst. Daisy comes out and lies at his feet. Walt covers his mouth as he coughs. A dime-sized circle of dark, red blood is left in the palm of his hand. Walt looks at the blood as he takes another sip of beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt continues to sit on his porch, a long row of empty Pabst beer cans are lined up on the railing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 46 Walt looks at a photo in his wallet, his and Dorothy's wedding photo. Walt looks down at Daisy -- WALT We miss Momma, don't we, Daisy. A vehicle pulls up to Tao's house. A party is in full swing. Sue comes out and helps the Hmong women unload big platters of food and carry them to the house. Sue catches Walt's gaze and steps over to his porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Walt, what are you up to? Walt points his index finger at the can of Pabst in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're having a barbecue. You want to come over?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's tons of food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll bet. Just keep your paws off my dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No worries, we only eat cats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm kidding, you moron. Come on, come on over. You can be my special guest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine right here. Walt reaches into the cooler for another beer. It's empty, just water and ice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son of a bitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 47 SUE What have you had to eat today, Walt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A piece of cake and some beef jerky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on over and get something to eat. We've got beer, too. Walt exhales loudly -- WALT Oh, what the hell. It's my birthday, I may as well drink with strangers instead of myself. Walt gets up and walks with Sue towards her house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy Birthday, Wally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't call me Wally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside are thirty Hmong and Walt, who sticks out like a sore thumb. Total fish out of water. Walt looks in the refrigerator, Sue looks over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do have a lot of beer, but no Pabst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they say, When in Hmong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ha ha. Are you sure it's okay I'm here? Everyone keeps looking at me and when I look back, they look at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's fine. Phong appears from the crowd and points at Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 48 PHONG (SUBTITLED) You, get out. Out of our house! (to Sue) What is he doing here? Walt cringes at her presence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd she say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She said welcome to our home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No she didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, she didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is this white man in our home? A man like him brings nothing, nothing but sorrow and death. Several relatives usher Phong away from Walt. The relatives are embarrassed at the outburst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hates me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, she hates you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did I do? A little Hmong girl walks past and Walt pats her on the head. Everyone in the room looks in horror at Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?! What the hell are all you fish heads looking at?! Sue looks around and then pulls Walt out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we should go in the other room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sue explains a few facts to Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 49 SUE A lot of the people in this house are very traditional. Number one, never touch a Hmong person on the head, not even a child. Hmong people believe that the soul resides in the head, so don't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's dumb, but fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmong people also consider looking someone in the eye to be rude. That's why everyone looks away when you look at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swell. Anything else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, some Hmong smile or grin when they're yelled at or get into a confrontation. It's a cultural thing. It expresses embarrassment or insecurity, not that they're laughing at you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good God, you people are all nuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt opens another beer, as Sue speaks Hmong to a relative. Walt notices an Old Hmong Man staring at him. Walt interrupts Sue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Sue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said you guys don't look you in the eye, but that guy keeps staring at me. Sue laughs and gestures to the Old Hmong Man. The Old Hmong Man steps over and nods to Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 50 SUE This is Kor Khue. He's the Lor family shaman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Witch doctor? Sue smiles and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something like that. The Hmong hold their clan Shaman in very high regards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boo-ga, boo-ga. Kor Khue says something to Sue in Hmong. She turns and translates to Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kor Khue is interested in you, he heard what you did. He says he would like to read you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants to read you. Tell you your soul. It'd be rude not to allow him this, it's a great honor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Kor to be my guest, fire away. Sue speaks Hmong to the Shaman. The Shaman responds and sits down across from Walt. He looks at Walt for a long time. Walt stares straight back at him. The Shaman mumbles to himself. Finally the Shaman turns to Sue and speaks very rapidly. As Sue translates, the Shaman watches Walt's reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kor Khue says that you think you've been disrespected. You do not live your life. Your food has no flavor. You are scared of your past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You stopped living years and years ago. Kor Khue says you're not at peace. Walt looks like he's been hit by a truck. The Shaman watches Walt closely, he knows he hit the nail on the head. Walt looks pale. He's been spooked good. He wipes sweat from his forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. Walt gets up and steps into the kitchen. He takes several deep breaths. He's pretty shook up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Je -- zuz -- Christ. Walt looks around at all the Hmongs eating and carrying on. Walt sees a young man give up his seat to an Elder. Walt sees a young woman go to each of the older folks and offer tea and cookies from a tray. Walt sees a child help an old man out of the bathroom. Walt coughs hard. He wipes blood from his lips. Sue comes in and looks at Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you okay? Walt brushes past her and goes into the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Walt washes his face in the sink and dries his hands. He's still pale. He looks long and hard in the mirror. Walt is stunned, it all adds up. Walt hasn't really lived in 50 years, he hasn't relaxed or exhaled or let his guard down since he got back from Korea in 1953.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself) Son of a bitch. I've got more in common with these goddamned gooks than my own spoiled-rotten family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt looks at himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy birthday. Walt opens the bathroom door. Sue stands there with a concerned look on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were bleeding? Walt smiles disarmingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just bit my tongue. I'm fine. I'm great. Let's get some of that gook food, I'm starving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt sits amongst several old Hmong Women, who take great delight in feeding him different Hmong dishes which he's obviously never tasted before. Walt reacts with great enthusiasm to the food, occasionally making jokes like he's choking, etc. This corny stuff goes over like gangbusters with the Hmong ladies. Sue comes in and rolls her eyes at Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, you glutton, let's go downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To mingle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine right here. I'm mingling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, you said not to leave you alone.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BASEMENT - SAME TIME 48 48 Walt and Sue descend the stairway. Walt is really out of his element down with all the Hmong teenagers. And the first person he sees across the room is Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, look who's over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's-his-name who tried to steal my Gran Torino.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My brother Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, Toad. Tao is in the corner, he avoids Walt's gaze. Sue walks over to a group of boys, leaving Walt alone. Walt doesn't know what to do with himself. He leans against the DRYER. The DRYER wobbles. Walt gets on his hands and knees. He looks under the dryer. He adjusts the short leg to balance out the machine. He just can't help it. All the Hmong kids watch Walt, trying not to laugh at this strange white man on his hands and knees fixing a dryer during a party. Walt looks up -- deer in the headlights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was wobbly, but I fixed it. It's fine now, shouldn't wobble anymore. The Hmong kids look away, covering their mouths with their hands. Walt glares at Tao, who immediately wipes the smile from his face. Sue walks over and hands Walt a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rice liquor. Try it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. Sue walks off. Walt sips his rice liquor and watches the interaction between the boys and girls. One particularly gorgeous young willow-wisp of a GIRL stares across the room at Tao. Tao looks back at her, but then looks away. The Girl keeps looking at Tao, smiling and twisting her hair. Tao doesn't approach her, but three other young men do. They do their best to charm her. She's polite, but not interested, she keeps looking at Tao. Walt laughs at Tao's ineptitude, shakes his head at this wasted opportunity. Suddenly the Girl steps over to Walt. She smiles -- WA XAM (GIRL) My friends and I were just wondering what you're doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good question. What am I doing here? Anyways, I'm Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Walt. I'm Wa Xam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wa Yum?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Wa Xam. So... what do you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? Not too much... I fix stuff I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I fixed my wife's friend's sink yesterday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I drove my aunt to the doctor to straighten out her prescription. Even fixed my screen door before it was broke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's one thing I've never been accused of. A bastard, yes. Funny, no. Wa Xam laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, have fun. I'm going to take off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pleasure to meet you, Yum Yum. She laughs at Walt butchering her name and goes upstairs. The three young suitors follow her up. Tao watches her. Walt comes over to Tao, who is startled. Walt laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relax, zipper head, whatta you think I'm gonna do, shoot you? Tao looks like he wants to run away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't say anything either, if I was you. Walt sips his rice liquor. Walt can't help but rib Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I knew you were a dipshit even before the whole garage deal, but I have to say you're even worse with women than you are stealing cars, Toad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Tao, not Toad. My name is Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good for you. Anyways, you're blowing it with that girl. Not that I give two shits about a Toad like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know what you're talking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wrong, egg roll. I completely know what I'm talking about. I know I'm not always the most pleasant person to be around, but I got the greatest woman who ever lived to marry me. I had to work at it, but I got her and it was the best thing that ever happened to me. Hands down. Walt points across the room. He sways slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you? You just sit there and watch as Ding Dong and Click Clack and Charlie Chan walk away with what's-her-face. She likes you, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was standing over there, orange dress, twisting her hair and smiling at you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean Wa Xam? Walt takes a long swig off his drink and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, yeah. Anyways, she likes you, I know, I talked to her. Great girl, charming girl. Love her. I love Yum Yum. But you? You just watch her walk out the door with the Three Stooges. Why? Because you're a big fat pussy! Walt drains his drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 57 WALT I gotta go home. Good luck, puss- cake. You need it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt empties the lawnmower bag as two elderly Hmong Women come over, each carrying a FLOWER BOUQUET.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No thanks. No more flowers. The elderly Hmong Women nod and speak rapid sentences in Hmong to Walt. He has no idea what they are saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more. Please, keep your flowers. The Hmong women nod, smile and chatter away, ignoring Walt. They walk past him and set the BOUQUETS on his porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, just put them on the porch. But that's it. No more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doorbell rings. Walt answers, a Skillsaw in one hand. Standing on his doorstep are three Hmong women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What now, Gee? Gee holds up a plate covered with tinfoil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Forget it. Stop bringing me stuff. Gee scolds Walt in Hmong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I've had it. Gee opens the corner of the tinfoil. Walt looks at the food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 58 WALT I can't. You have to stop. Gee pulls the tinfoil off. Walt gazes at the food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that the chicken dumpling thing you brought the other day?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt pulls up in his pickup truck. Sue and Vu wait on Walt's porch. Tao stands out on the sidewalk. Walt gets out of his pickup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What now? What? Vu rambles on in Hmong. Walt looks at his watch. He looks at Sue for the translation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao is here to make amends, he's here to work for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No he's not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother says that Tao dishonored the family and now he has to work off his debt. He'll start tomorrow morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The kid is useless, I don't even want him on my property. I thought we already went over that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's very important to my mother that you accept. It'd be an insult to refuse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is this all of a sudden turned around on me? The goddamned kid tries to steal my car and somehow I'm the bad guy if I don't accept?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 59 SUE My family is very traditional and it will very much upset them if you don't let Tao repay... Tao interrupts from the sidewalk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Sue. If he doesn't want to, let's just go. Sue and Vu yell at Tao to shut up at the same time; Sue in English, Vu in Hmong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up. Shut up! Shut up!! Tao looks at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Walt sees the earnest looks on the Hmong women's faces. Their expression begs Walt. Walt gazes back at Tao. Walt looks disgusted, he exhales loudly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Great. Tomorrow. Walt walks past them and into his house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, Joseph and Mary. These Hmong broads are like badgers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt sits drinking coffee and reading the newspaper. Tao walks sheepishly over to the property line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son of a bitch, I didn't think he'd show. Walt waves Tao over. Tao barely looks at Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. What are you good at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I'm asking. What are you good at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're gonna work for me, I have to know what you can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's about what I expected. Okay, why don't you go over by the spruce tree and count how many birds feed at the bird feeder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Count the birds?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, you can count? You slopes are supposed to be good at math, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I can count.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao stands in Walt's garden with his arms folded. Walt walks over to trim weeds around the garden fence. Walt doesn't even look at Tao. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want it done right, that's why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you've got me just standing here. What am I supposed to be doing, anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scaring away crows. Tao shoots Walt a dirty look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a perfect job for you, plus you people don't seem to mind squinting in the sun all day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt waters a flower bed. Tao comes over and stands there. Walt finishes watering before even looking at Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you have for me today? You want me to watch paint dry or maybe count the clouds that pass by?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't get flip with me, zipper head. I ain't the one who tried to steal and don't forget it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead. I don't care if you insult me and say racist things. I'll take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That I know. You have no teeth, kid. That's your problem. You have no balls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm stuck here. Why don't you give me something useful to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because unlike you I'm not useless. I maintain my property, whereas you swamp rats let your houses go to hell. Walt looks across the street at one very dilapidated house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute... How long do I have you for? Tao pauses... he doesn't want to answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long, Toad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 62 TAO (QUIETLY) Till next Friday. Walt laughs out loud. It makes Tao cringe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go get my ladder out of the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao is at the top of the LADDER. Walt and the Hmong neighbor grin at him from the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you're done caulking the siding, nail that gutter back up, I can see it right out my kitchen window, it's been bugging me for three years. The neighbor says something in Hmong to Walt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said it, brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao digs up a big TREE STUMP out in the rain. It's hard, draining labor and Tao is covered with mud. Tao's shovel hits rocks and roots and clay. Misery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Tao do various chores; scrape paint, hang screen doors, reattach house numbers, trim bushes, etc. Walt scrutinizes his every move. Tao is a virtual slave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt watches with great satisfaction as Tao paints one of the neighboring houses. The neighborhood is really shaping up. Walt sips his coffee with a slight grin. He is really, really, really enjoying this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 63 A very old Hmong man and his very young GRANDSON walk up Walt's driveway. The Grandson translates for grandpa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa says he want to know if you can have Tao clear out the big wasp nest under our porch? Walt reaches in his pocket and studies a small note pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see why not. (GRINS ) Tell him sometime after lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao walks up the sidewalk. Before ringing the doorbell, Tao looks down at his hands which have several CALLOUSES on them. Tao rubs his hands with a smile. This has been the first time Tao has really risen to a task presented to him. Tao reaches for the doorbell...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt stands over the sink, coughing. In the b.g. the doorbell rings. Walt coughs up a big spot of blood, it's thick with fibers. The doorbell rings again. Walt wipes his mouth and runs the water in the sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt answers the door, just as Tao rings the doorbell a third time. Walt looks angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Lord almighty, knock it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my last day, whatta you want me to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take the day off, you've done enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 64 Tao looks disappointed, but says nothing. He nods and starts to walk away. Walt calls after him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Toad. Tao turns around. Walt wants to say something, but stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing, never mind. Walt shuts the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt sits in the crowded waiting room. He looks around. He's the only WHITE PERSON in the room. Even most of the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is African or from India. As Walt waits, names are called out such as Alvarez, Ngaima, Yang and Abdalla. Finally when the name Kowalski is called, the Muslim woman can't pronounce it correctly. Walt winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt sits in a chair, his hands folded in his lap. A short Asian man in a doctor's smock comes in with a chart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Kowalski?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon. I looked over your paperwork and I think we should immediately start on a full battery of tests. I feel that this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute. Where's my regular doctor, where's Dr. Fellman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE 65 ASIAN DOCTOR Dr. Fellman retired three years ago. I'm his replacement, Dr. Chang.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ.

direction.raw_text: Good.

direction.raw_text: . WALT'S FRONT YARD - DAY 65 65 While Walt fills a bird feeder, he notices Tao next door. Tao stands, tiptoed on the top of a six-foot ladder, trying to cut a high branch with a pole saw. Walt shakes his head and walks over to Tao.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, moron. Tao is startled and almost falls off the ladder.

direction.raw_text: What?

direction.raw_text: I appreciate you're doing something on your own, but you're the only person I know dumb enough to get himself killed trimming tree branches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't stand on the top step of a ladder and if you cut through that branch you're hacking away at, you'll end up kaput. Tao looks and sure enough -- a thick, black POWER LINE is five feet below the branch he's almost severed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go grab the extension ladder from my garage and I'll show you how to do it right, zipper head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tao ties up bundles of branches and twigs. Walt lights a cigarette, looks up in the tree and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks good. Good job. Tao nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Make sure you put the ladder back when you're done raking up the leaves.

direction.raw_text: I know. I will. Walt walks back over to his porch, grabs a Pabst from the cooler and watches Tao rake. A white Honda turns the corner and drives slowly past Tao. Smokie and Spider smile menacingly at Tao as they pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This kid doesn't have a chance. The Honda now slowly passes Walt's house. Walt just stands there, sipping his beer. The Honda slows to a stop and the gangbangers glare at Walt. The REAR WINDOW of the Honda opens. Walt holds out his RIGHT HAND like a GUN. He closes one eye to better aim his imaginary gun and moves his thumb several times as if firing. Bang -- bang -- bang. The Honda takes off. Walt watches it drive off and lights another cigarette. Walt doesn't notice, but Tao witnessed this whole interaction from his yard.

direction.raw_text: The doorbell rings. Walt opens his door. Tao stands there with his hands in his pockets. He's a bit apprehensive.

direction.raw_text: For the love of Pete.

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It must be a hundred degrees in here, turn on the fan. Tao flips the switch on the CEILING FAN, the fan wobbles and shakes, it looks like it's about to fly off. Walt stares up at the fan and shakes his head.

direction.raw_text: Hand spade. Tin snips. Nail punch. Tack hammer. Putty knife. Wire stripper. Drywall saw. Tile spacers. Silence. Walt can see something is bothering Tao, but he's too uncomfortable to speak up -- WALT What?

direction.raw_text: This is for you. Roll of duct tape, can of WD-40 and a pair of vise-grips. Any man who's worth a shit can do half his household jobs with these three things. In the odd chance that doesn't work out, you can borrow something.

It's too much weight for Walt, but this doesn't stop him from heaving and pulling. Walt could have done this by himself when he was younger. Walt sits down on the step and breathes hard.

direction.raw_text: So tell me the problem with Hmong boys again. I'm not completely clear.

direction.raw_text: Not sure. No.

direction.raw_text: The boys don't ask their fathers for advice, because over here, their fathers no longer have the answers.

direction.raw_text: (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Hmong boys become almost invisible, they end up banding together and it all goes to hell from there.

direction.raw_text: The girls go to college and the boys go to jail.

direction.raw_text: It's more common than not. Walt reflects on this for awhile, then changes the subject.

direction.raw_text: You still going out with that clown?

direction.raw_text: No. I dumped him. He was a dim- wit. Walt nods.
